div.sent: Almost half of the population in Bangladesh is women.
The development of society or the advancement of the country is not possible keeping this half deprived of rights or letting them fall behind.
Begum Rokeya has compared a man and a woman with two wheels of a car.
If one wheel is bigger and the other is smaller, the car cannot move forward smoothly.
Similar is the case with our society.
Women play the main role in childcare.
Thus the future of the nation is built in their hand.
Women of Bangladesh lag behind men in many ways.
They are still deprived of economic rights, social rights, cultural rights and many more.
They are also victims to many types of discriminations.
Many parents in our country consider a female child a burden.
They think a male child, after growing up, will earn to feed his parents and will hold the helm of the family.
From this mentality parents prefer a male child to a female child.
But the situation is changing now.
Girls are also coming forward equally with boys to take up the responsibilities of a family and the society.
Similarly, the society's attitude to women, although slowly, is also changing.
Our constitution and government regulations give women equal status with men as citizens.
They have equal rights as men in services, in other professions and in case of wages.
But in real life women are deprived of these rights in many respects.
They are victims of deprivation in family and in society, too.
A family does not show equal interest in educating a female child as to a male child.
Especially in villages, girls are married away in minor ages.
As a result, girls are not allowed to go beyond primary or secondary levels despite being good students.
Besides, there are instances of physical and mental tortures too.
We read many news of violence against women in daily newspapers.
Equal rights of men and women are acknowledged in the constitution of Bangladesh.
Equal rights of women are also mentioned in the United Nations charter about removing discrimination towards women.
Here equal rights mean equal rights along with men in family, in society, in state, that is, every stage in national life.
It is not that men and women are equal only in casting votes and in opportunity of contesting in polls.
Women and men should have equal rights in educational institutions, job and employment, salary and wages and in all respects.
To mention mother's name has been made mandatory with the name of the father, whereas the previous rule was to mention father's name only.
The Government has made strict law to stop violence against women including acid violence.
Maternity leave for women has been extended.
Women have started to get benefits of these steps.
But a total change will not come without spread of education and raising consciousness in society.
But it is clear that women in Bangladesh are growing conscious about their rights.
The biggest evidences are their participation in various meetings, associations and organisations.
